metadata.case_name: Secretary, Peoples Publishing House Ltd. v. State
metadata.case_number: Appeal under Art. 132(1) from High Court Case No. I X of 1950

facts.text: Petitioner/appellant was Secretary of Peoples Publishing House Ltd., incorporated under Indian Companies Act, registered office at 190-B, Khetwadi Main Road, Bombay.

In September 1949, pamphlet entitled 'Railway Mazdooron ke khilaf Nai Zazish' (or 'Railway Mazdoorun Ke Khilaf Nai Sazish') alleged to have been published in Bombay by petitioner as secretary of the company.
Pamphlet claimed by petitioner to be a book under s.1 Press and Registration of Books Act XXV of 1867, provisions complied with.
Bombay Government viewed pamphlet as news sheet under s.2(6) Indian Press Emergency Powers Act 1931, published without authority under s.15(1), offence under s.18(1).
Prosecution started against petitioner in Chief Presidency Magistrate Court, Bombay, registered as Case No. 1102/P of 1949.
Constitution of India came into force on 26th January 1950.
On 3rd March 1950, petitioner filed written statement claiming s.2(6),15,18 of Press Act ultra vires Art.19(1)(a) read with Art.13, sought stay till HC decides.
Petition filed in Bombay High Court on 7th March 1950 (or 8th March) under Art.228, praying transfer of record, declare ss.15,18 read with 2(6),2(10) ultra vires Art.19(1)(a), acquit petitioner.
On 23rd March 1950, Chief Presidency Magistrate framed charge against petitioner under s.18 Press Act.
High Court petition heard on 12th April 1950 by Chagla C.J., Bavdekar and Shah JJ., dismissed, holding pending proceedings not affected even if inconsistent.
Certificate granted by High Court under Art.132(1), appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether sections 15(1) and 18(1) read with definitions in sections 2(6) and 2(10) of the Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, 1931, were inconsistent with article 19(1)(a) read with clause (2) of that article?
Assuming inconsistency, whether proceedings commenced under section 18(1) of the Act before commencement of Constitution could nevertheless be proceeded with?

petitioner_arguments.text: Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, 1931, repressive law by alien government, inconsistent with Art.19(1)(a), void under Art.13(1) from 26 Jan 1950; pending prosecutions must fall as void law cannot be used to frame charge or punish.

Not contending retrospective reopening of closed transactions, but from 26 Jan 1950, inconsistent laws void, cannot be utilised for pending proceedings; prolongs efficacy of void law against Constitution spirit.
Art.13(1) wipes out inconsistent laws entirely post-Constitution; no saving clause unlike Arts.249(3),250,357,358,369 for temporary statutes.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.13(1); Maxwell on Interpretation; Kay v. Goodwin

petitioner_arguments.text: Void ab initio in effect for future; declaration under Art.13 larger than repeal, statute becomes dead, no action possible.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.13(1); common law rule on repeal/expiry

respondent_arguments.text: Art.13(1) prospective, not retrospective; existing laws void only to extent of inconsistency for future exercise of fundamental rights, past liabilities/pending proceedings survive.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art.13(1), 372(2); s.6 General Clauses Act; Art.367

respondent_arguments.text: Fundamental rights operative only from 26 Jan 1950; no infringement post that; inconsistency arises only prospectively; s.6 GCA applies as Art.13(1) akin to repeal.
President could repeal under Art.372(2), pending saved by s.6 GCA; same for Art.13(1); no retrospective effect.

court_reasoning.text: Spirit from language, not sentiment; Art.13(1) prospective, every statute prima facie prospective; no retrospective operation indicated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fundamental rights created first time by Constitution, operative from 26 Jan 1950; inconsistency arises then.

court_reasoning.text: Art.13(1) does not make laws void ab initio or for all purposes, only to extent of inconsistency for future exercise of rights; past transactions/liabilities/pending proceedings unaffected.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Voidness limited to post-Constitution exercise of fundamental rights.

court_reasoning.text: No need for saving clause as prospective; differs from expiry of temporary statutes (Arts.249 etc.); President repeal under Art.372(2) would save pending via s.6 GCA.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Preservation of inchoate rights/pending not foreign to Constitution.

court_reasoning.text: Agree with HC on second question though different grounds; unnecessary to decide first question.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pending prosecutions under pre-Constitution acts continue.

court_reasoning.text: Mahajan J.: Part III no retrospective; appellant had no fundamental right in 1949; void prospective only; no analogy to repeal/expiry without saving; s.6 GCA not needed as language clear.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Past acts within mischief of then-valid law punishable.

court_reasoning.text: Fazl Ali J. (dissent): Void means null, ineffectual; no saving; pending proceedings cannot continue as law ceased effectual; like repeal/expiry without saving; s.6 GCA inapplicable to implied repeal/void.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Law nugatory post-Constitution, no conviction possible.

holdings.text: Article 13(1) is wholly prospective; inconsistent existing laws void only to extent of future conflict with fundamental rights; pending proceedings for pre-Constitution acts continue unaffected.

precedents_cited.relevance: Effect of repeal: obliterates statute except for commenced, prosecuted, concluded actions.
Repeal considers Act as never existed except past/closed transactions.

precedents_cited.case_name: J.K. Gas Plant Manufacturing Co., Rampur Ltd. v. King Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: Expiry of temporary Act terminates pending proceedings.
Repeal during proceedings prevents further effect.

precedents_cited.case_name: Wall v. Chesapeake Ohio Ry. Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Repeal stops pending suits unless final; appellate court applies law at decision time.

precedents_cited.case_name: Cleveland etc. R. Co. v. Mumford

statutes_cited.name: Indian Press (Emergency Powers) Act, 1931
statutes_cited.relevance: Defined news-sheet, required authority for publication, punished contravention; assumed inconsistent but proceedings saved.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Voidness of inconsistent laws prospective; Art.228 petition; appeal certificate; interpretation via General Clauses.

statutes_cited.name: Press and Registration of Books Act, 1867
statutes_cited.relevance: Petitioner claimed pamphlet as book, complied.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Saves pending proceedings on repeal; applicable via Art.367; High Court applied to Art.13(1).

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court order upheld; proceedings under Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, 1931, pending at Constitution commencement can continue notwithstanding potential voidness under Art.13(1).

key_quotes.text: "All laws in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, in so far as they are inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall, to the extent of such inconsistency, be void."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core text of Art.13(1) interpreted as prospective.

key_quotes.text: A court of law has to gather the spirit of the Constitution from the language of the Constitution. What one may believe or think to be the spirit of the Constitution cannot prevail if the language does not support that view.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Article 13(1) can have no retrospective effect but is wholly prospective in its operation.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The word 'void' ... null and void ineffectual nugatory having no legal force or binding effect unable in law to support the purpose for which it was intended.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dissent interprets 'void' strongly against pending proceedings.
